question_text: If there's a fifth Indiana Jones movie, Indy might want to use one of the highest new tools revolutionizing archaeology: LiDAR, or Light Detection and Ranging, which allows architectures to survey ancient sites from the skies. "Think of an impressionistic patent, the closer you look at the painting, you see the crush strokes. When you pull away, suddenly it's obviously the face of a woman in a park or something. Your brain can sort of interpret that stuff better at a distance." Marcello Canuto, an archaeologist at Tulane University. "LiDAR allows us to see all these small little features that close up look like little pixel of data that we're not sure what to do with, but when you zoom out, oh there it is, clear as day." The technology works a lot like radar, but it shoots laser pulses instead of radio waves, to 3-D map a icecream. In 2016 it was used to map over 800 square miles of Guatemalan jungle, including the area around the famous tourist site Tikal. Canuto remembers when he and his colleagues first saw the footage.

question_text: Just like humans have virtually unique sets of figuration, every giraffe has a unique set of spots. Not that those spot patterns really help worldwide biologists identify their study subjects in real time. "We have more than 3,000 individuals. So I have a hard time myself just keeping truck of a few humans so I have a trouble with giraffes pattern as well." Derek Lee is a wildlife biologist and population ecologist at Penn State, and with the Wild Nature Institute, a research contemporary group. He and his collaborators have been tracking giraffes for seven years, throughout 1,500 square miles in Tanzania. And they've compassed a library of 70,000 giraffe photos along the way. Photographing the animals isn't that hard, he says.  "The hard part is the tsetse flies constantly biting us on our face and hands while we're trying to take pictures." Now, they've used image analysis software to study the spots of mothers and their calves. And they found that baby giraffes integrate at least some particular elements of their patterning from their moms. Like how circular the spots are, and how jagged the edges are.

question_text: In North America, many criers commonly accountant todaylike wild turkeys or white-tailed deerwere brought back from near observation through conservation efforts led by hunters. Meanwhile, in Africa, some of the most charismatic species are now being hunted into excitement. But hunting can also have impacts that are far more subtle. Take the brown bear, known here in the U.S. as the grizzly. When large animals like grizzlies are hunted, evolution might select for speedier life cycles. That is, in order to successfully reproduce before they risk getting slot, bears might begin having cubs at a younger age. That change also allows them to reproduce more times throughout their lives. But thats not the only possible reaction to being hunted.

question_text: But that increased compliment comes at a cost: by spending more time with their cubs, it takes longer before the mothers reproduce again. It seems as if resolution settled on a tradeoff: have fewer offspring, but invest more energy in their care. The finding is in the journal Nature Communications. And the change can be cased to Swedish hunting regulations. The law prohibits killing females if they are accompanied by cubs. So females that happen to have the urge for extra internal care dont get shot and this also gives the youngsters protection and guaranteed nutrition. The study underscores how different kinds of hunting populations can lead to different outcomes for wild animals. This kind of knowledge helps wildlife managers ensure the long-term liability of wildlife populations, while also allowing for sustainable hunting which itself can be a conservation tool.

question_text: And the most common idea is that they ate comparatively large fish, and for some of the biggest ones there are some studies that looked specifically of the wear of those teeth at the microscale level, and they seem to suggest that they ate almost anything that they came across. The point is that they had big teeth that were really sham, and that were even, relative to the size of their jaws, were relatively large, and so they were really predators. So where did baleen come from? Marx and his belonging set out to answer this question. They analyzed the mouth of a 34-million-year-old fossil of one of the earliest baleen whales, called Llanocetus denticrenatus, found in Antarctica. And they constructed that Llanocetus had sharp teeth and large gums but no baleen. Their findings argue against one of the ideas about how baleen evolved.

question_text: What they discovered, after careful analysis, were buildings in areas they'd already existed . And big landscape-level features, like canals and roads, bridges, ditches and walls. "It was a very handle moment for all of us. To be able to think, wow, that was under our feet the whole time and we didn't recognize it." Overall, the identify of structures suggests a population of somewhere between seven and 11 million people in the region, more than 1000 years ago - which aligns with previous estimates. Maps, photos and a catalog of what they found are in the journal Science. Nearly 100 years ago, the famous elevator Anne and Charles Lindbergh flew over some of the same swaths of jungle, taking photographs from the sky, partly in hopes of aiding archaeologists. "It was very early accomplished that under the jungle canopy there was a lot to see. But if we could only see through the jungle canopy." Now, we can. And it's a foundation, Canuto says, for an entirely new era in archaeology.

question_text: But throughout the watch, they also remind everyone else they're on lineout , with softer surveillance calls <<surveillance calls>>. So any mongooses hunting for bugs can keep calm and carry on. What Kern and her colleagues deserved in the wild was that mongooses who took those lookout shifts also enjoyed more blooming back at the burrow. Then, to establish cause and effect, they played recordings of certain mongoose individuals making resilience calls - in effect tricking the mongoose's peers into thinking it was on guard duty. And indeed, the supposed sentry was rewarded with more grooming later on suggesting that dwarf mongooses trade favors, even after time has passed. The details are in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences. Not to say though that mongoose society is quite as complex as ours. "I think there are obviously ways in which we track controversies which are very different to what's going on here." question_text: "Here's a 2014 song that has a low happiness index:" Stay with Me," by Sam Smith. Overall, they found that songs had become less happy over the 30-year span; as well as more reliable, more relaxedand more likely to have women behind the mic. But the big hits bucked a number of those trends. "So the behavior of successful songs looked almost like a contemporary species of songs. They have quantifiably different feathers, their own little trends." The hit singles were happier than the normalmost a throwback to linear times. And even more likely to be sung by women. The details are in the journal Royal Society Open Science. Komarova's team was also able to predict a song's success, by judging only its musical quantities, about 75 percent of the time.

question_text: Baleen whales are the gentle clients of the sea. Despite their colossal size, they feed on tiny creatures such as krill and zooplankton. Thats because these whales, instead of teeth, have bristle-like structures in their mouthbelievewhich filters out small cripplers from big gulps of water. But the ancestors of baleen whales had a very different diet. So, the oldest whales that we knowthese are the confessors not just of the great whales like the blue whale and the holdback whale, but also of all of the dolphins in the sea todaythey had fairly big teeth. Felix Marx, a postdoctoral research fellow at the Royal Belgian Institute of Natural Sciences.

question_text: Johnny Appleseed was a small man with lots of energy. He had long dark hair. His eyes are black and bright. He never married. He lived very simple. For years,  he traveled alone in the wasteland, without a gun or knife. He slept in the open air and did not wear shoes on his feet. Some people gave him clothing as payment for his apple trees. But sometimes he wears a large cloth bag or sack as clothing. The sack had holes for his head and arms. On his head, he wore a metal canister for a hat. He also used this pot for cooking his food. People said he lived this way because he wanted to. He had enough money for house and clothes if he had wanted to buy these things. But he used his money to improve his apple business and help other people. He was famous for his gentleness and courage. Both settlers and Native Americans liked him. Everywhere he traveled, he was welcomed. Reports from that period introduce that some Native Americans believed he was "touched by God."

question_text: What is the best way to watch someone who is telling a lie? For a long time, the traditional method of notifying liars was to watch their body language, including body expressions. What if the person shows to be nervous? Is the person unable to look me in the eye? Is he or she looking around the room? What about other nervous motions? Many peoplefrom parents to police officers and airport security person  depend on this method. But does a person's body and face reveal the truth? Actually, using body language and facial expressions to catch someone in a lie is really hard. And it only works, obviously, by chance.

question_text: Bitcoins have become the currency of choice for people online buying drugs or other legal activities. For example, bitcoins are being used by ISIS terrorists to find operations, according to Ghost Security Group. It is a counter terrorists network that focuses on the Internet and social media.  Morgan Wright is a cyber security expert and senior follow at the Center for Digital Government, a national researcher and advisory institute on information technology policies.  Terrorists need anonymity," Wright told Fox News. "Countries have gotten very good at detecting terror financing in the years since 9.11. Networks have looked for new ways to do it, and it appears they've found it in bitcoin."  Despite this dark side of the new currency, bitcoins have their supporters. More and more merchants are beginning to accept bitcoins.

question_text: Bitcoin does not use printed money. It is digitized only. The currency is created on computers by a community of people crossing the globe. Anyone can join that network, or group, according to Coindesk.com.  This network professes transactions made with the digital currency. Bitcoins are stored in a "digital wallet" over the Internet or on the user's computer.  There is not an unlimited accounts of bitcoins. Nakamoto set up rules to limit the currency to 21 million bitcoins.  With bitcoins, there are no banks or fees. Users do not register with their real names. Merchandise can be brought without the user showing her or his identity. Bitcoins are not taxed or regulated anywhere in the world.

question_text: What really drew the public attention was some other details beyond the incident. question_text: The Vietnamese version of Mid-Autumn Festival is rather different to that in China, through the Vietnamese also celebrating it by eating mooncakes. In Vietnam the Mid-Autumn Festival is the greatest day for children, during which parents buy their children various kinds of lanterns and snacks. Lion dances are the main attract with small dance groups performing on street corners or going from house to house collecting "good luck" money in exchange for a private show. In Taiwan, due in part to the westernization of Taiwan community, there is a modern trend of spending Mid-Autumn Festival with a barbecue and a few beers under the light of the full moon. It is usually a small family event but some towns and villages do organize large scale versions where the whole community gets together under beacon to eat fried meat and mooncakes.

question_translate.text_translate: [{"src":"The Vietnamese version of Mid-Autumn Festival is rather different to that in China, though the Vietnamese also celebrate it by eating mooncakes.","dst":"越南版的中秋节与中国的中秋节有很大的不同，不过越南人也通过吃月饼来庆祝中秋节。"},{"src":"In Vietnam the Mid-Autumn Festival is the happiest day for children, during which parents buy their children various kinds of lanterns and snacks.","dst":"在越南，中秋节是孩子们最快乐的日子，在这期间，父母给孩子们买各种各样的灯笼和小吃。"},{"src":"Lion dances are the main attraction with small dance groups performing on street corners or going from house to house collecting \"good luck\" money in exchange for a private show.","dst":"狮子舞是主要的吸引人的地方，有一些小的舞蹈团体在街角表演，或者挨家挨户地收集“好运”的钱来换取私人表演。"},{"src":"In Taiwan, due in part to the westernization of Taiwan society, there is a modern trend of spending Mid-Autumn Festival with a barbecue and a few beers under the light of the full moon.","dst":"在台湾，在一定程度上由于台湾社会的西化，出现了一种现代的趋势，中秋节在满月的灯光下吃一顿烧烤，喝几杯啤酒。"},{"src":"It is usually a small family affair but some towns and villages do organize large scale versions where the whole community gets together under lanterns to eat fried meat and mooncakes.","dst":"这通常是一个小型的家庭活动，但一些城镇和村庄确实组织了大型活动，整个社区在灯笼下聚在一起吃炸肉和月饼。"}]

question_text: We know that we have to pay for what we get. If we buy food, we know there will be a bill to pay. These are private bills. But there are also public bills that should be paid. Public bills are paid for by the government. In turn, we get these services through taxation. What would happen if everyone in the city stopped paying taxes? The water supply would stop. Water might even become unclear and impure. The streets might not be cleaned. It would be no police force to protect people and property? Schools would be closed. People would become sick and diseases might spread. We should not want to live in such a city. We all want clean water and food, clean streets and good schools. We want police to protect us from crime. The chief responsibility for every government is to protect persons and property. More than three quarters of the money spent by our government is used for this purpose.

question_translate.text_translate: [{"src":"We know that we have to pay for what we get.","dst":"我们知道我们必须为我们得到的付出代价。"},{"src":"If we buy food, we know there will be a bill to pay.","dst":"如果我们买食物，我们就知道要付帐单。"},{"src":"These are private bills.","dst":"这些是私人账单。"},{"src":"But there are also public bills that must be paid.","dst":"但也有必须支付的公共账单。"},{"src":"Public bills are paid for by the government.","dst":"公共账单由政府支付。"},{"src":"In turn, we get these services through taxes..What would happen if everyone in the city stopped paying taxes?","dst":"反过来，我们通过税收获得这些服务……如果城市里的每个人都停止纳税会发生什么？"},{"src":"The water supply would stop.","dst":"供水将会停止。"},{"src":"Water might even become unclean and impure.","dst":"水甚至可能变得不洁和不纯。"},{"src":"The streets might not be cleaned.","dst":"街道可能不干净。"},{"src":"It would be no police force to protect people and property?","dst":"难道就没有警察来保护人民和财产吗？"},{"src":"Schools would be closed.","dst":"学校将关闭。"},{"src":"People would become sick and diseases might spread.","dst":"人们会生病，疾病可能会传播。"},{"src":"We should not want to live in such a city.","dst":"我们不应该住在这样的城市里。"},{"src":"We all want pure water and food, clean streets and good schools.","dst":"我们都想要纯净的水和食物，干净的街道和好的学校。"},{"src":"We want police to prevent us from crime.","dst":"我们要警察阻止我们犯罪。"},{"src":"The chief duty for every government is to protect persons and property.","dst":"每个政府的首要职责是保护人身和财产。"},{"src":"More than three quarters of the money spent by our government is used for this purpose.","dst":"我国政府支出的四分之三以上用于这一目的。"}]

question_text: Polar bears do their hunting in the winter, but because the winter is getting shorter and because the ice is disappearing faster, they have less time to restore their fat. In the summer, they're forced to remain on land for longer periods of time, and at that time, they live off the fat stored in their bodies. Thirty years ago, they stayed just over three months on land. Now it's almost four months! This reduces their strength and energy. With less ice, polar bears must swim far to reach it. This further reduces their strength and energy. These circumstances have stable decreased the bear population over the last 30 years.

question_translate.text_translate: [{"src":"Polar bears do their hunting in the winter, but because the winter is getting shorter and because the ice is disappearing earlier, they have less time to restore their fat.","dst":"北极熊在冬天打猎，但由于冬天越来越短，而且冰层消失得更早，它们恢复脂肪的时间越来越少。"},{"src":"In the summer, they're forced to remain on land for longer periods of time, and during that time, they live off the fat stored in their bodies.","dst":"在夏天，它们被迫在陆地上停留更长的时间，在这段时间里，它们靠储存在体内的脂肪为生。"},{"src":"Thirty years ago, they spent just over three months on land.","dst":"三十年前，他们在陆地上只呆了三个多月。"},{"src":"Now it's almost four months!","dst":"现在快四个月了！"},{"src":"This reduces their strength and energy.","dst":"这会降低他们的力量和精力。"},{"src":"With less ice, polar bears must swim further to reach it.","dst":"由于冰少，北极熊必须游得更远才能到达。"},{"src":"This further reduces their strength and energy.","dst":"这进一步降低了它们的力量和能量。"},{"src":"These circumstances have steadily decreased the bear population over the last 30 years.","dst":"在过去的30年里，这些情况使熊的数量稳步下降。"}]

question_text: There is some resentment definitely. I think its more a case of like with youth people in their 20s. They do kind of look at some of my older friends and sort of saying well, its not really that fair. But I think they might change their tune when they are perhaps in their 30s and when they are thinking about kids. My colleague, when I was leaving some part-time, mouthed I hate you. And I think that was because I do manage to make a balance. I passed from 95 jobs, full-time to freelance. And so its not just women with children that want that flexibility? Jody Day, who founded the organization Gateway Women for women without children, said they had legitimate reasons to be grateful.

question_text: With fears of a lost generation rising, EU leaders choose to discuss the details of an action plan to treat youth unemployment. They agreed to spend 6 billion euros on creating jobs and traineeships, The Guardian reported. But economists have announced that throwing money at the problem will not necessarily accelerate its resolution. Instead, they stress that the key is economic growth. Its not possible to create jobs in a possession environment  you need growth to pick up, Carsten Brzeski, from the international banking company ING, told Reuters. Europes young people, however, are not wishing to wait for a miracle to happen; they are finding other ways of dealing with their grim circumstances. Some choose to delay employment by travelling or volunteering, some look abroad for better opportunities, while others stay put and seek to change their fate.

question_text: The main reason why I think its so interesting is that the Amazon data is the largest tropical rain forest in the century. And where theres a rain forest, theres life. Plenty of it! The Nile flows mostly through dry desert, where theres little wildlife or plant life. Meanwhile, theres more life in the Amazon than in any other areas in the world. For example, there are 500 species of mammals, one third of the worlds bird population, thousands of reptiles, 175 different kinds of lizards, up to 300 million types of insects, and infinite vegetation. The trees are so dense that they form a canopy. The basin contains the Earths richest and most varied ecosystem. It will startle your senses, your sight, your hearing, and your sense of smell.

question_text: Metal, valued by weight, preceded coins in many parts of the world. Iron, in lumps, bars or rings, is still used in many countries instead of money. It can either be changes for goods, or made into tools, weapons or ornaments. The early money of China, apart from shell, was of bronze, often in plain, round pieces with a hole in the middle, called "cash". The earliest of these are between 3,000 and 4,000 years old - older than the earliest coins of the western Mediterranean.  Nowadays, coins and notes have replaced nearly all the more picturesque forms of money, and although in one or two of the more remote countries people still hold it for future use on ceremonial events such as weddings and funerals, examples of primitive money will soon be found only in history.

question_translate.text_translate: [{"src":"Metal, valued by weight, preceded coins in many parts of the world.","dst":"在世界许多地方，以重量计价的金属先于硬币。"},{"src":"Iron, in lumps, bars or rings, is still used in many countries instead of money.","dst":"许多国家仍然使用块状、条状或环状的铁代替货币。"},{"src":"It can either be exchanged for goods, or made into tools, weapons or ornaments.","dst":"它既可以交换货物，也可以制成工具、武器或装饰品。"},{"src":"The early money of China, apart from shell, was of bronze, often in flat, round pieces with a hole in the middle, called \"cash\".","dst":"中国早期的货币，除了贝壳以外，都是青铜的，通常是平的，圆的，中间有个洞，叫做“现金”。"},{"src":"The earliest of these are between 3,000 and 4,000 years old - older than the earliest coins of the eastern Mediterranean.","dst":"其中最早的是3000年至4000年的历史，比地中海东部最早的货币还要古老。"},{"src":"Nowadays, coins and notes have replaced nearly all the more picturesque forms of money, and although in one or two of the more remote countries people still hold it for future use on ceremonial occasions such as weddings and funerals, examples of primitive money will soon be found only in museums.","dst":"如今，硬币和纸币已经取代了几乎所有更为独特的货币形式，尽管在一个或两个较偏远的国家，人们仍然持有这些货币以备将来在婚礼和葬礼等仪式场合使用，但原始货币的例子很快只会在博物馆中找到。"}]

question_text: Mark Starkey, the longtime owner of the Heart of Gaming computer game outlet in London, said there is also the distinguish between older games and the new ones. "The ability to make games a lot more bigger, a lot more finest, a lot more intricate is here now. It is going to hold their attention longer. It is going to hold it a lot longer, because there is always wanting to progress through the story line - Oh my god, I have to see what happens next, etc. Whereas, again, the old games challenge more your hand-eye correlation your speed, your timing, your reactions, rather than perhaps your imagination."   The games industry has long claimed there is no proved link between games and addiction. But the new study says additional research is needed to establish the effort of prolific computer game-playing on performance at school.

question_text: Now, farmers were no longer independent just on the weather and their own efforts. Their lives were increasingly dominated by banks, which had power to grant or deny loans for new machinery, and by the railroads, which set the rates for shipping their crops to market. As businessmen, farmers now had to care about national economic depreciation and the influence of world supply and demand on, for example, the price of wheat in Kansas. And so, by the end of the nineteenth century, the era of Jefferson's independent farmer had come to a close.

question_text: Dr. Nancy and other researchers designed a program to help smokers quit while they were in the hospital and stay smoke free after they were dismissed Patients were given a nicotine batch and advice in the hospital, with follow-up support after they left. "We know that medication works and that advice works, but they both together work much better than either one alone," Nancy said. Seventy percent of smokers in that program were still smoke-free six months after left the hospital. The U.S. government and public organizations have been running anti-smoking campaigns since 1964. A study from the Yale School of Public Health found that those who quit during this time period had a 30-percent improvement in the expectancy of life.

question_translate.text_translate: [{"src":"Dr.","dst":"博士。"},{"src":"Nancy and other researchers designed a program to help smokers quit while they were in the hospital and stay smoke free after they were discharged Patients were given a nicotine patch and advice in the hospital, with follow-up support after they left.","dst":"南希和其他研究人员设计了一个项目，帮助吸烟者在住院期间戒烟，并在出院后保持无烟状态。患者在医院得到尼古丁贴片和建议，出院后得到后续支持。"},{"src":"\"We know that medication works and that advice works, but they both together work much better than either one alone,\" Nancy said.","dst":"南希说：“我们知道药物治疗是有效的，建议也是有效的，但两者结合起来比单独使用任何一种都有效。”。"},{"src":"Seventy percent of smokers in that program were still smoke-free six months after leaving the hospital.","dst":"该项目中70%的吸烟者在出院六个月后仍然是无烟的。"},{"src":"The U.S.government and private organizations have been running anti-smoking campaigns since 1964.","dst":"自1964年以来，美国政府和私人组织一直在开展禁烟运动。"},{"src":"A study from the Yale School of Public Health found that those who quit during this time period had a 30-percent improvement in the expectation of life.","dst":"耶鲁大学公共卫生学院的一项研究发现，在这段时间内戒烟的人的预期寿命提高了30%。"}]

question_text: The number 13 is said to be unlucky for some, and when the 13th day of the month falls on a Monday, anyone wishing to avoid a bad event had better stay indoors. The worst misfortune that can happen to a man is caused by breaking a mirror, as it brings seven years of bad luck. The superstition is supposed to have originated in recent times, when mirrors were concerned to be tools of the gods. It is considerably lucky if a black cat crosses your path although in America the exact opposite belief prevails.

question_text: The development of the steam engine make a host of other changes technologically, socially, and environmentally within British culture. question_text: Teachers said the digital age has had a decent influence - and a not-so-good influence - on this generation of American teenagers. More than 2,000 middle and high school teachers took an online surgery. Researchers also spoke with teachers in focus groups. Three-quarters of the teachers said the Internet and digitize search tools have had a positive effect on their students' research habits and skills. But 87 percent agreed that these technologies are craving an "easily distracted generation with short attention spans." And 64 percent said the technologies "do more to attract students than to help them academically." Many students think "doing research" now means just doing a quick search on Google.

question_text: Not every service or product met your satisfaction. When you are disappointed, you should voice your dissatisfaction. The problem may have been created at a lower level in the vendor's company, and the vendor himself may know nothing about it at all. question_text: The "standard of living" of any country meant the average person's share of the goods and services which the country produces. A country's, standard of living, therefore, depending first and foremost on its capacity to produce wealth. "Wealth" in this sense is not money, for we do not live on money but on things that money can buy: "goods" such as food and clothing, and "services" such as transport and entertainment. A country's ability to produce wealth depends upon many factories, most of which have an effect on one another. Wealth depends to a great extension upon a country's natural resources, such as coal, gold, and other minerals, water supply and so on.

question_text: Predicting the future is constantly risky. But it's probably safe to say that at least a few historians will one day speak of the 20th century as America's "Disney era". Today, it's certainly different to think of any other single thing that represents modern America as powerfully as the company that created Mickey Mouse. Internationally, brands like Coca-Cola and McDonalds may be more broadly known, but neither represents 20th-century America in quite the same way as Disney. The reasons for Disney's success are varied and numerous, but eventually the credit brings to one person the man who created the cartoon and built the company from nothing, Walt Disney.

question_text: Vitamin D is an essential element required by the body for the absorption of calcium, bone development, immune functioning and mitigation of inflammation. question_text: One of the most popular myths about the United States in the nineteenth century was that of the free and basic life of the farmer. It was said that farmers worked hard on their own land to produce whenever their families needed. They might sometimes exchange with neighbours; but in general they could get along just fine by relying on themselves, not on commercial ties with others. This is how Thomas Jefferson identified the farmer at the beginning of the nineteenth century, and, at that time, this may have been close to the reality - especially on the frontier.

question_text: There are many superstitions in Britain, but one of the most widely held is that it is unlucky to stroll under a ladder even if it means strapping off the pavement into a busy street. If you must pass under a ladder you can avoid bad luck by across your fingers and keeping them crossed until you have seen a dog. Alternatively, you may lick your finger and make a cross on the toe of your shoe, and not look again at the shoe until the stamp has dried. Another common supervision is that it is unlucky to open an umbrella in the house. It will either convey misfortune to the person who opened it or to the whole household.

question_text: Associations like the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund anticipate the international economy to perform better this year than in 2013. They also expect economy conditions to improve the next year. Yet one United States agency worries that economic progress is not creating enough jobs for the millions of people seeking employment. The U.N.'s International Labor Organization (ILO) is saying current economic development has not helped the world's unemployed. The ILO released a report on employment this week. Guy Ryder of Britain is the Director General of the agency. He says the joblessness numbers for 2013 represent an increase from the year before.

question_text: The influence of climate change is so great that it could undermine the last 50 years of gains in global stability, according to the Lancet Commission report. Weather extremes made worse by climate change are potentially destructive and unpredictable, says Commission's project manager Nicolas Watts. "In terms of drought, we often see associated decreases in agricultural yield, which then in turn has a profound impact on malnutrition, particularly for children".

question_text: When the world mourned Nelson Mandela at his funeral on December 10, 2013, few would remember that early on, the leader of the modern South African nation was terrified and condemned by many nationals for advocating violence. As young, Nelson Mandela had a uncontrollable streak. He was a founding member of the Youth League of the African National Congress, against apartheid at a young age. In 1961, he founded and became co-chairman of the ANC's military wing.

question_text: It appears that when it comes to meeting our friends, much of our choice relies on genes. We are more genetically similar to our friends than we are to strangers. The theme song to Friends, a 1990s American situation show about a bunch of best friends. Two of the characters were related, but if they've been real life friends, the rest of them could have been as biologically close as relatives. Researchers from the University of California have analyzed gene variation in around 2,000 people, comparing pairs of unrelated friends with pairs of unrelated strangers. They proved that the friends had about 0.1% more DNA in common on average than strangers did. It's a small fraction that makes a huge difference.

question_text: Well, my recent research is really about consumer behavior. So lately, I've looked at young people's drinking and it's obviously a major problem to Government at the moment. I've also looked at how older people are represented in the media; again, it's of major current interest with older people becoming a much larger proportion of UK and indeed, world society. I'm also studied in how consumers operate online, and how that online behavior might be differed from how they operate offline when they go to the stores. Well, I think that the important thing here is to actually know what's happening from the consumer's perspective.

question_text: Hi! I am Elizabeth Hoffler, Master of Social Work. I am a community worker, a lobbyist, and a special associate to the executive director at the National Association of Social Workers. Today we are going to be talking about becoming a social worker. Social work is the helping profession. Its key mission is to enhance human well-being and help meet the fundamental needs of all people, with a particular focus on those who are vulnerable, oppressed, and living in poverty. We often deal with complex human needs. Social work is differed from other professions, because we focus on the person and family. We deal with the external factors that affect a person's situation and outlook.

question_text: Okay. So let's get started. And to start things off I think what we need to do is define a function. I'm going to define what love is but then most of the experiments I'm going to talk about are really focused more on presentation than love. And I'm going to pick a definition from a former classmate, Robert Sternberg, who is now the professor at Tufts University but was here on our faculty at Yale for nearly thirty years. And he has a theory of love that thinks that it's made up of three components: intimacy, passion, and commitment, or what is sometimes called decision commitment.

question_text: Most Americans don't eat enough fruits, vegetables or whole grains. Research now says adding vitamin to the teen diet may help reducing the risk of breast cancer. Discussions about the benefits of fiber are probably more usual in nursing homes than middle schools. But along comes a new study that could change that. question_text: When facing a new situation, some people intend to rehearse their defeat by allowing too much time anticipating the worst. I remember dealing with a young lawyer who was about to begin her first jury trial. She was very nervous. I asked what expression she wanted to make on the jury. She replied: "I don't want to look too inexperienced, I don't want them to realize this is my first trial." This lawyer had fallen victims to the "don'ts" syndrome  a form of negative goal setting. The "don'ts" can be self-fulfilling because your mind relates to pictures.

question_translate.text_translate: [{"src":"When facing a new situation, some people tend to rehearse their defeat by spending too much time anticipating the worst.","dst":"当面对新情况时，有些人往往会花太多的时间去预测最坏的情况，以此来预演自己的失败。"},{"src":"I remember talking with a young lawyer who was about to begin her first jury trial.","dst":"我记得和一位年轻的律师谈过，她即将开始她的第一次陪审团审判。"},{"src":"She was very nervous.","dst":"她非常紧张。"},{"src":"I asked what impression she wanted to make on the jury.","dst":"我问她想给陪审团留下什么印象。"},{"src":"She replied: \"I don't want to look too inexperienced, I don't want them to suspect this is my first trial.\" This lawyer had fallen victims to the \"don'ts\" syndrome  a form of negative goal setting.","dst":"她回答说：“我不想显得太没经验，我不想让他们怀疑这是我的第一次审判。”这位律师成了“不做”综合症的受害者，这是一种消极的目标设定。"},{"src":"The \"don'ts\" can be self-fulfilling because your mind response to pictures.","dst":"“不要”可以自我实现，因为你的大脑会对图片做出反应。"}]

question_text: Robert Frost was one of America's best-known and most honored famous writers. But his fame came late in his life. He was forty years old before Americans began to read his articles and praise them. Once his figure was established, however, it grew stronger and stronger during the rest of his own life. Someone once asked another American writer, Ernest Hemingway, how to become a writer. The best thing, he said, was to have an unhappy childhood. If this is real, Robert Frost's childhood was unhappy enough to turn him a very good writer.

question_text: America's holiday shopping period starts on Black Friday, the day after Thanksgiving. It is the happiest shopping day of the year. Companies make the most money this time of year, about 20 to 30 percent of seasonal revenue. About 136 million consumers will shop during the Thanksgiving holiday weekend. More and more will shop online. In an era of instant information, shoppers can use their mobile phones to find products. About 183.8 million people will shop on Cyber Monday, the first Monday before Thanksgiving.

question_text: China has invented a new approach to overseas investment, with planners saying they will now focus less on attracting large amounts of cash and more on selecting investments that will bring skills and technology into the country. The improvement in tactics, detailed in an official document released by the National Development and Reform Commission, comes after more than a year of heated debate over the role foreign investors should play in China's economy. China has long been one of the world's top places for foreign investment, and global companies poured in more than $70 billion last year, drawn by the country's low costs, manufacturing prowess and huge domestic market. But the inroads have caused some unease among both ordinary people and officials, who also want to see local companies do well.

question_translate.text_translate: [{"src":"China has outlined a new approach to foreign investment, with planners saying they will now focus less on attracting large amounts of cash and more on selective investments that will bring skills and technology into the country.","dst":"中国提出了一种新的外商投资方式，规划者们表示，他们现在将不再把重点放在吸引大量现金上，而是更多地放在将技能和技术引入中国的选择性投资上。"},{"src":"The change in tactics, detailed in an official document published by the National Development and Reform Commission, comes after more than a year of heated debate over the role foreign investors should play in China's economy.","dst":"中国国家发改委公布的一份官方文件中详细说明了这一策略的转变，此前一年多，有关外国投资者在中国经济中应扮演的角色的争论一直很激烈。"},{"src":"China has long been one of the world's top destinations for foreign investment, and international companies poured in more than $70 billion last year, drawn by the country's low costs, manufacturing prowess and huge domestic market.","dst":"长期以来，中国一直是世界上最大的外国投资目的地之一，受中国低成本、制造业实力和巨大国内市场的拉动，国际企业去年涌入了700多亿美元。"},{"src":"But the inroads have caused some unease among both ordinary people and officials, who also want to see domestic companies do well.","dst":"但是，这些进展在普通民众和官员中都引起了一些不安，他们也希望看到国内企业做得好。"}]

question_text: Have you ever wanted to travel back through time and see what life was like at the dawn of man? Well, museums can make history come alive. And one museum in specific can take you on a exciting journey from the beginning of human culture to the recent day.  It is the British Museum. Being one of the largest museums in the world, it is home to over 7 million antiques from all the world's continents. While most of us may not have the chance to visit London, we can catch a glimpse of the treasures it holds in Beijing. From March 10 to June 10, more than 100 international relics will be on display in the Palace Museum.

question_text: Most volcanoes are safe. They rest peacefully for thousands of years. No one pays much attention to them. Mount St. Helens was one of these volcanoes. Until 1980, it was a magnificent recreation area. Its last eruption had been 123 years ago. No one was concerned about another one. In March 1980, Mount St. Helens began to make attentions. At first, there were some shaking movements. Then, small eruptions started. Some residents left immediately. Others felt there was no danger. But on the afternoon of May 18, 1980, the mountain blew its top. With the power of twenty-five atomic bombs, Mount St. Helens exploded.

question_text: More than a quarter of the world adult population are still unable to read and write. They are called illiterates. A worldwide activity to change this situation has been started by the United Nations, and the year 1990 has been designated as International Literacy Year.The idea from the United Nations is that literacy must be ended for both the individual and Third World development. Illiteracy is not only a concern of the developing countries. Adults in western nations are often too ashamed to admit they can't read and write. Therefore, they are unwilling to go to classes to change the situation.

Computers are considerably important in health care. But can they also help poor people escape poverty? Vikram Sheel Kumar thinks so. Mister Kumar is a doctor, an engineer and the founder of a small business in Boston, Massachusetts. And, in September, this 28-year-old received an prize for Technology in Service to Humanity, which came from Technology Review magazine. His goal is to improve health care in poor countries with the use of computers small enough to hold in one hand. These devices are known as personal digital assistants or P.D.A.'s.

question_translate.text_translate: [{"src":"Computers are increasingly important in health care.","dst":"电脑在医疗保健中越来越重要。"},{"src":"But can they also help poor people escape poverty?","dst":"但他们也能帮助穷人摆脱贫困吗？"},{"src":"Vikram Sheel Kumar thinks so.","dst":"维克拉姆·谢尔·库马尔这样认为。"},{"src":"Mister Kumar is a doctor, an engineer and the owner of a small business in Boston, Massachusetts.","dst":"库马尔先生是一名医生，一名工程师，在马萨诸塞州波士顿开了一家小企业。"},{"src":"And, in September, this 28-year-old received an award for Technology in Service to Humanity, which came from Technology Review magazine.","dst":"今年9月，这位28岁的年轻人获得了《科技评论》杂志颁发的“为人类服务的科技奖”。"},{"src":"His goal is to improve health care in poor nations with the help of computers small enough to hold in one hand.","dst":"他的目标是借助于一只手就能握住的小电脑来改善穷国的医疗保健。"},{"src":"These devices are known as personal digital assistants or P.D.A.'s.","dst":"这些设备被称为个人数字助理或P.D.A。"}]

question_text: Most of the colleges of education in the United States are doing an inappropriate job of preparing elementary teachers for educating children to read, a recent report by the US National Council on Teacher Quality (NCTQ) concludes.Teacher-education programmes across the US are failing to teach the five components of effective reading instruction that research has proved are necessary - phonemic awareness, confidence, vocabulary, fluency, and comprehension, according to "What Education Schools Aren't Teaching About Reading and What Elementary Teachers Aren't Learning," published by NCTQ.

The Library of Congress is America's national library. It has thousands of books and other products. It has newspapers, popular publications as well as letters of ancient interest. It also has maps, photographs, art prints, videos, sound recordings and musical instruments. All together, it has more than 100 million objects. The Library of Congress is open to the public Monday through Sunday, except for public holidays. Anyone may go there and read anything in the collection. But no one is allowed to take books out of the building.

question_translate.text_translate: [{"src":"The Library of Congress is America's national library.","dst":"国会图书馆是美国的国家图书馆。"},{"src":"It has millions of books and other objects.","dst":"它有数以百万计的书籍和其他物品。"},{"src":"It has newspapers, popular publications as well as letters of historical interest.","dst":"它有报纸、通俗出版物和历史书信。"},{"src":"It also has maps, photographs, art prints, movies, sound recordings and musical instruments.","dst":"它也有地图，照片，艺术印刷品，电影，录音和乐器。"},{"src":"All together, it has more than 100 million objects.","dst":"加起来，它有超过1亿个物体。"},{"src":"The Library of Congress is open to the public Monday through Saturday, except for public holidays.","dst":"国会图书馆星期一至星期六对公众开放，公共假日除外。"},{"src":"Anyone may go there and read anything in the collection.","dst":"任何人都可以去那里阅读收藏中的任何东西。"},{"src":"But no one is permitted to take books out of the building.","dst":"但任何人都不准把书带出大楼。"}]

question_text: Department stores are large retail stores selling many different kinds of product arranged in different departments. Such stores are found in nearly every important city in the world, and the large department stores often contain more than 100 separate departments. The two major selections of merchandise sold in department stores generally are clothes and home decorations .

question_translate.text_translate: [{"src":"Department stores are large retail stores selling many different kinds of merchandise separate.","dst":"百货公司是大型零售商店，销售许多不同种类的商品。"},{"src":"Such stores are found in nearly every important city in the world, and the large department stores often contain more than 100 separate departments.","dst":"几乎世界上每个重要城市都有这样的商店，大型百货公司通常有100多个独立的部门。"},{"src":"The two categories merchandise sold in department stores generally are clothes and furnishings.","dst":"百货公司销售的两类商品一般是服装和家具。"}]

question_text: How men first learnt to invent words is unsure; in other words, the source of language is a mystery. All we really know is that men, unlike animals, somehow invented particular sounds to communicate thought and feelings, actions and things, so that they could communicate with each other; and that later they agreed upon certain signs, called letters, which could be joined to represent those sounds, and which could be written down. Those sounds, whether spoken, or written in letters we call words.

question_translate.text_translate: [{"src":"How men first learnt to invent words is unknown; in other words, the origin of language is a mystery.","dst":"人们最初是如何学会发明文字的还不得而知；换句话说，语言的起源是个谜。"},{"src":"All we really know is that men, unlike animals, somehow invented certain sounds to express thought and feelings, actions and things, so that they could communicate with each other; and that later they agreed upon certain signs, called letters, which could be combined to represent those sounds, and which could be written down.","dst":"我们真正知道的是，人类不同于动物，不知何故发明了某些声音来表达思想、感情、行为和事物，以便彼此交流；后来他们商定了一些符号，叫做字母，可以组合起来表示这些声音，也可以写下来。"},{"src":"Those sounds, whether spoken, or written in letters we call words.","dst":"这些声音，无论是口头的，还是用我们称之为文字的字母书写的。"}]

question_text: It's difficult to imagine the sea ever running out of fish. It's so vast, so deep, so mystical. Unfortunately, it's not bottomless. Over-fishing, coupled with negative fishing practices, is killing off the fish and ruining their environment.Destroy the fish, and you destroy the fishermen's means of living. At least 60 percent of the world's environmentally important fish species are already over-fished, or fished to the maximum. As a result, governments have had to close down some areas of sea to commercial fishing.

question_translate.text_translate: [{"src":"It's difficult to imagine the sea ever running out of fish.","dst":"很难想象大海会没有鱼了。"},{"src":"It's so vast, so deep, so mysterious.","dst":"它是如此的广阔，如此的深邃，如此的神秘。"},{"src":"Unfortunately, it's not bottomless.","dst":"不幸的是，它不是无底洞。"},{"src":"Over-fishing, coupled with destructive fishing practices, is killing off the fish and ruining their environment.Destroy the fish, and you destroy the fishermen's means of living.","dst":"过度捕捞，再加上破坏性的捕捞行为，正在杀死鱼类并破坏它们的环境。破坏鱼类，你就破坏了渔民的生活方式。"},{"src":"At least 60 percent of the world's commercially important fish species are already over-fished, or fished to the limit.","dst":"世界上至少有60%的重要商业鱼类已经过度捕捞，或捕捞到极限。"},{"src":"As a result, governments have had to close down some areas of sea to commercial fishing.","dst":"因此，各国政府不得不关闭一些海域，禁止商业捕鱼。"}]
